title: Extraordinary Measures in Dire Emergencies
summary: Allows extraordinary measures in dire emergencies; often cited as the legal basis for Section 31.
text:
Article 14, Section 31 of the Federation Charter is referenced as permitting “extraordinary measures” in times of grave emergency.
On-screen material links this clause to the controversial intelligence apparatus known as “Section 31.”
In circumstances that threaten the security or existence of the Federation, executive authorities may authorize exceptional steps
that would otherwise be outside routine Starfleet procedure. Interpretations vary by era and jurisdiction.

title: Civilian Authority Over Starfleet Officers (Emergency Orders)
summary: Recognizes circumstances where ranking Federation officials may issue direct orders to Starfleet personnel.
text:
This regulation has been cited in cases where a ranking Federation official assumed directive authority over a Starfleet operation during an active emergency.
Typical use involves search‑and‑rescue or civil protection scenarios when immediate action is required and Starfleet’s chain of command is unavailable
or superseded by intergovernmental mandate. Invocation remains subject to later review by Starfleet Command and the Federation Council.

title: Temporary Civilian Command of Starfleet Vessels
summary: Authorizes ranking Federation officials to assume direct command of Starfleet vessels under specific emergency conditions.
text:
Title 15 of the Galactic Emergency Procedures codifies the limited transfer of operational control to ranking civilian officials in narrowly defined emergencies.
The scope is temporary, mission‑bound, and requires subsequent reporting to Starfleet Command. This authority is typically constrained to life‑safety or
interstellar public‑order incidents when delay would create unacceptable risk.

title: The Prime Directive (Non‑Interference)
summary: Prohibits interference with the natural development of alien cultures; later styled the Prime Directive and paramount over most other orders.
text:
General Order 1 establishes the Federation’s foundational rule of non‑interference with the internal development of other cultures, especially pre‑warp societies.
It forbids actions—overt or covert—that would alter a civilization’s natural evolutionary trajectory, even when intervention appears benevolent.
Exceptions are rare and narrowly tailored (e.g., to remedy prior contamination or catastrophic errors). The Omega Directive is one of the few instruments
that can supersede it in scope‑limited cases.

title: Prohibition on Unnecessary Force
summary: Forbids the unnecessary use of force by Starfleet personnel against Federation members or sentient beings.
text:
General Order 2 articulates a bright‑line standard against the unnecessary application of force. It aligns operational conduct with Federation values,
requiring de‑escalation and measured response in civil and interstellar contexts. Violations are subject to review and sanction under Starfleet justice procedures.

title: Respect for Member Sovereignty and Local Law
summary: Requires Starfleet personnel to observe the statutes and ordinances of Federation member worlds within their jurisdictions.
text:
General Order 3 balances Federation cohesion with planetary sovereignty. When operating within a member world’s jurisdiction, Starfleet personnel are obligated to
observe all applicable local statutes and ordinances, subject to higher‑order constitutional guarantees and duty exceptions. Sanctions may include local penalties
and Starfleet disciplinary action.

title: Capital Offense Exception (Legacy)
summary: Historically referenced as the sole death‑penalty exception in certain 23rd‑century sources; exact elements remain unspecified in canon.
text:
General Order 4 is cited in some 23rd‑century records as the “only exception” to the Federation’s prohibition on the death penalty, though its exact scope
is not clearly defined in surviving canon materials. Later commentary frequently discusses GO‑4 in relation to GO‑7 and the evolving legal stance on capital punishment.

title: Talos IV Prohibition (Capital Crime)
summary: Forbade travel to or contact with Talos IV; long considered the only capital offense on the books.
text:
General Order 7 barred any Federation vessel from visiting Talos IV, elevating violations to a capital crime for reasons held at the highest classification levels.
The policy aim was to protect Federation personnel from the Talosians’ psychogenic capabilities and the broader risks of exposure.
Subsequent eras softened or rescinded the penalty structure, but the historical prohibition remains a landmark in Starfleet jurisprudence.

title: Nonmilitary Resolution Prior to Engagement
summary: Requires attempts at first contact and nonmilitary resolution before engaging alien species in battle.
text:
Directive 010 formalizes escalation control: before initiating combat with an alien power, commanders must attempt first contact and seek a peaceful resolution.
The rule provides commanders with a defensible checklist for diplomacy under high tension while preserving the right of self‑defense if threatened.

title: Right Against Self‑Incrimination
summary: Affirms that accused individuals are not required to answer questions—an analogue to the Seventh Guarantee.
text:
Directive 101 codifies procedural protections for the accused, aligning Starfleet practice with Federation civil liberties doctrines.
It mirrors protections summarized in the Seventh Guarantee of the Federation Constitution and applies to both line and civilian proceedings.

title: Superseding Canon Name for General Order 1
summary: Canonical name and framing for General Order 1’s non‑interference principle.
text:
The Prime Directive is the commonly used designation for General Order 1. Over time, official communications and training materials adopted the name
to emphasize the rule’s moral centrality and precedence in decision‑making.

title: Absolute Priority to Neutralize Omega Phenomena
summary: Authorizes any and all means to destroy Omega molecules; overrides other directives including the Prime Directive.
text:
The Omega Directive activates in the presence of Omega molecules, whose destabilizing effects threaten subspace itself.
Once invoked, it grants commanding officers broad latitude—up to and including actions otherwise barred by policy—to neutralize the threat.
Access to briefing materials is compartmentalized at the highest levels.

title: Non‑Interference in Historical Events
summary: Forbids direct interference in established history, even to correct perceived injustices.
text:
The Temporal Prime Directive extends non‑interference into the temporal domain, instructing personnel to avoid actions that would alter established timelines.
Enforcement is coordinated with temporal affairs bureaus where present and may involve containment, memory remediation, or timeline restoration protocols.

title: Security Escort Requirement for Hostile Engagements
summary: States the captain will not engage a hostile force without protection of a security officer.
text:
This tactical directive hardens bridge resource management during combat operations by requiring security‑officer coverage for command staff during hostile engagements.
The directive encapsulates lessons learned from boarding actions and surprise incursions.

title: Mandatory Meal Breaks
summary: Requires meal breaks at regular intervals; cited across multiple centuries.
text:
Section 48 Alpha‑7 establishes minimum rest and nutrition standards for duty rosters. Shipboard operations adapt the rule to watch cycles and mission tempo,
but the baseline requirement is persistent across eras for crew health and performance.

title: Prohibition on Taking Intelligent Life
summary: Codifies Starfleet’s regulation against the taking of intelligent life.
text:
Starfleet Order 2 encapsulates the presumption against lethal force where sentient life is concerned. While self‑defense remains authorized, the order demands
strict necessity and proportionality and underpins training in rules of engagement.

title: Flag Officer Assumption of Command
summary: Permits a flag officer to assume command of a starship in the captain’s absence when necessary.
text:
This provision enables a flag officer to take command of a vessel whose assigned captain is absent or incapacitated, provided necessity is established.
It ensures continuity of command in crises and is paired with medical and psychological safeguard clauses.

title: Medical Relief of Command
summary: Authorizes relief of a flag officer or commanding officer upon certified medical or psychological unfitness.
text:
Section C provides a due‑process pathway to relieve an officer—up to and including a flag officer—on medical or psychological grounds.
Certification by the chief medical officer or equivalent admissible evidence is required; the standard protects the ship while preventing capricious removals.

title: Self‑Destruct Authorization
summary: Permits deliberate matter‑antimatter mix to scuttle a starship as a last resort.
text:
Order 2005 authorizes a commanding officer to initiate destruct procedures to prevent capture or catastrophic misuse of Federation technology and personnel.
The order is a last resort and involves multi‑party authentication and automated failsafes.

title: Formal Relief by Successor
summary: Specifies the process by which a successor formally relieves a commanding officer.
text:
This order defines the handoff protocol for command reliefs, including notification, verification of authority, and log entries.
It ensures continuity of operations and reduces disputes about lawful command.

title: Neutralize Security Threats to Strategic Installations
summary: Grants authority to neutralize threats to Deep Space 9 by any means necessary (disputed in‑universe attribution).
text:
Referenced in the context of Deep Space 9, this special order purportedly authorized “any means necessary” to neutralize security threats to the station.
Some accounts attribute the order to a simulated environment; nonetheless, the formulation reflects wartime posture during the Dominion conflict.

title: Emergency Preservation of Life
summary: Authorizes captains to preserve crew lives by any justifiable means in imminent‑destruction scenarios.
text:
Regulation 3, Paragraph 12 gives commanding officers emergency latitude to preserve life when destruction is imminent.
The rule has been cited to justify extreme measures, but its scope does not shield unlawful acts against non‑combatants.

title: Arrest & Surrender Protocols
summary: Outlines how officers must consider themselves under arrest pending charges before senior officers.
text:
This provision codifies custody etiquette inside the chain of command. When charges are presented without immediate hearing,
the accused officer is to consider themself under arrest and respond per the senior‑officer present rule until a competent authority adjudicates.

title: Weapons Transfer Restrictions
summary: Prohibits transfer of weapons to other races without Federation Council approval.
text:
Regulation 15 restricts proliferation by requiring high‑level authorization for any weapons transfer outside Starfleet control.
Starship captains must secure Council authorization before facilitating such transfers, even in allied theaters.

title: Ban on Genetically Modified Individuals in Starfleet
summary: Explicitly prohibits genetically modified individuals from serving in Starfleet.
text:
This article codifies service ineligibility for individuals with proscribed genetic modifications.
Limited waivers may exist in extraordinary circumstances, but the baseline rule remains exclusionary pending policy reforms.

title: Ethical Conduct & Academic Integrity
summary: Referenced in the alternate reality as a cadet ethics/code provision used in cheating cases.
text:
In the alternate reality, Regulation 17.43 appears in Academy disciplinary contexts involving academic dishonesty.
Though jurisdiction‑specific, it underscores Starfleet’s zero‑tolerance stance on falsified performance.

title: Assumption of Command in Emergencies
summary: Allows an officer to take command when an imminent threat exists, lives are in danger, or no equal/higher‑ranking officer is available.
text:
Section C supplies a clear triad of triggers—imminent threat, danger to citizens, or absence of senior officers—under which an officer may lawfully assume command.
After‑action reviews scrutinize whether the triggers were genuinely met.

title: Weapons Transfer (Duplicate Citation)
summary: A second citation of weapons‑transfer prohibitions; retained for cross‑reference parity across eras and sources.
text:
Some sources list Regulation 25, alongside Regulation 15, as the controlling weapons‑transfer restriction.
Compliance auditing treats these as harmonized constraints; authorization still requires Federation Council approval.

title: Personal Log Sealing
summary: Requires personal logs to remain sealed unless released by order of Starfleet Command.
text:
Section B protects crew privacy and operational security by sealing personal logs.
Access requires an explicit order from Starfleet Command or a competent judicial authority.

title: Impulse Reactor Coolant (IRC) Tank Pressure
summary: Sets conservative pressure variance limits for IRC tank storage, authored by Montgomery Scott.
text:
A technical standard for impulse power systems, 42/15 prescribes conservative pressure margins to improve safety and reliability.
The author, Montgomery Scott, noted the tanks could tolerate more, but the regulation intentionally bakes in caution.

title: No Uncoded Transmissions Under Fire
summary: Forbids uncoded messages on open channels if transmissions are being monitored during battle.
text:
46A mitigates signals‑intelligence risks by prohibiting uncoded transmissions in combat when enemy monitoring is suspected.
Exceptions require direct authorization and are logged for post‑action review.

title: Prohibition on Aiming Phasers at Fellow Officers
summary: Bars pointing a phaser at fellow officers without valid cause.
text:
A basic safety and discipline rule: do not bring a weapon to bear on fellow officers absent lawful justification.
Violations trigger security referral and, where applicable, court‑martial charges.

title: Minimize Participation in Historical Events
summary: Requires officers to minimize participation in historical events (time travel/temporal anomalies).
text:
This regulation operationalizes temporal caution for crews encountering time travel or historical displacement.
Actions must be narrowly tailored to mission survival and non‑disruptive to recorded history.

title: Combat Command Precedence
summary: In multi‑ship combat, command falls to the vessel with tactical superiority absent a higher‑ranking officer.
text:
Invoked in inter‑vessel engagements to establish clear command precedence, this article reduces confusion and conflicting orders in battle.
“Tactical superiority” is evaluated on survivability, maneuver, and armament in the moment.

title: Active Captain Override
summary: Permits an active captain to override orders of other officers within defined limits.
text:
Paragraph 2 emphasizes that an active, duly recognized captain retains authority to countermand orders that jeopardize mission integrity or safety,
subject to review for abuse of discretion.

title: Officer Conduct
summary: Requires conduct befitting an officer at all times.
text: A general‑conduct clause mandating professionalism, restraint, and adherence to Starfleet’s code of ethics on and off duty.

title: Weapons Transfer Restrictions (Alternate Numbering)
summary: Another enumerated restriction on transferring weapons without Council approval; retained for cross‑reference.
text:
Certain sources adopt alternate numbering for the weapons‑transfer rule. Operationally it mirrors Regulations 15 and 25:
do not transfer weapons without Federation Council authorization.

title: Relinquishment of Command Due to Compromise
summary: Requires a CO to relieve themself if emotionally compromised and unable to make rational decisions.
text:
A safeguard against impaired decision‑making in crisis. The regulation expects candid self‑assessment by the CO,
reinforced by medical and senior‑officer oversight.

title: Weapons Transfer Restrictions (Alternate)
summary: Yet another enumerated weapons‑transfer prohibition; maintained for cross‑reference parity.
text: Mirrors the substance of Regulations 15/25/498, reflecting variant numbering across eras and records.

title: Handling Unstable Substances in Oxygen Atmospheres
summary: Mandates special handling for certain unstable compounds in oxygen atmospheres.
text:
A safety regulation cited in engineering logs specifying containment and handling protocols for hazardous materials in O2 environments.
Linked updates reference compatible storage media and restricted areas.

title: Antimatter Containment
summary: Requires antimatter to be stored in magnetic confinement pods due to volatility.
text: This engineering standard codifies antimatter storage in magnetic confinement, with alarm thresholds, inspection cadence, and emergency venting procedures.

title: Wartime Conscription Authority
summary: Allows a Starfleet captain to conscript almost any person into service during a time of war.
text: Conscription authority is tightly bounded to declared or de facto wartime conditions and is subject to post‑action audit and automatic sunset after hostilities.

title: Prohibition on Permanent DNA Modification
summary: Bans permanent DNA modification of personnel.
text: A bioethics regulation proscribing germline or persistent somatic modifications to Starfleet personnel, save for tightly controlled medical exceptions.

title: Armed & Ready Until Contact
summary: Requires away teams to remain armed and ready to defend themselves until contact is made.
text:
This standing protocol directs away teams to remain armed and on defensive posture until formal contact and threat assessment are complete.
It evolved from repeated ambush scenarios and hostile‑environment landings in the 23rd–24th centuries.

title: Minimum Two‑Person Teams
summary: Requires away teams to consist of more than one member except in extraordinary circumstances.
text:
To mitigate isolation risk and provide immediate mutual support, away team deployments are structured as at least two personnel.
Solo exceptions require commanding‑officer authorization and documented necessity.

title: Ultritium 283 & Class‑K/Cryogenic Prohibition
summary: Prohibits the use of ultritium 283 in class‑K environments or cryogenic substrates; updated per stardate 43094.3.
text:
3984/A enumerates environmental prohibitions for explosive compound ultritium 283.
The directive was updated on stardate 43094.3 to clarify class‑K and cryogenic handling restrictions after incident reviews.

title: Safety Standards for Specific Compounds in Class‑N(2) Environments
summary: Lists safety regulations for balter compound 298 and tri‑nickolas powder in Class‑N(2) planetary environments.
text:
This Starfleet‑Federation Regulatory Authority item prescribes containment, PPE, and transport limits for designated compounds
used in industrial or scientific contexts on Class‑N(2) worlds.

title: Form of Address for Command
summary: Establishes 'sir' as standard address to a commanding officer; naval tradition uses 'captain' for ship COs.
text:
The protocol standardizes forms of address to maintain clarity and respect within command hierarchies. While some COs prefer alternatives (e.g., “ma’am”),
the baseline is “sir,” and by naval tradition a ship’s commanding officer may be addressed as “captain,” irrespective of rank.

title: Yellow Alert on Laser Targeting
summary: Calls for declaring yellow alert if a starship is targeted by laser weapons.
text:
A legacy operations note reflecting early contact eras: when targeted by laser‑class weapons, the ship is to go to yellow alert pending threat assessment.
Though lasers are archaic relative to phasers and disruptors, the protocol endures as a conservative safety practice.

title: EMH Conduct During Hostile Takeover
summary: Directs the Emergency Medical Hologram to deactivate and await rescue in the event of hostile control of the ship.
text:
To prevent coercion or misuse during shipboard seizures, Protocol 28, Subsection D instructs the EMH program to deactivate and await Starfleet recovery operations.
Medical continuity plans require designated biological personnel to assume triage while the EMH remains offline.
